Regent had applied to England for assistance lh's

their hostility towards Portugal or an underiah

Earl Bathurst concluded his speech by moving
that humble address be presented 10 his AlaIestt

and expressing the hope which their Lordshps en-

,y's Governmen, would awaken he King Of Spain

venting a recourse to arms while Al the same Tune

their cordial concurrence ard support, in MAINTAIN
ing the independence OF Portugal, the oldest and
mos, faithful ally oi Great Bi'an' The molten

ion, and the Marquis OF I4ansdown. all oi whom

istcrs Lord Holland and the Duke os Wellington
both believed the prompt despatch OF body OF troops

a war The motion carried unsnimouSly.

Canning moved the answer To the Kings message
and made very able and interesting speech lie
entered into a minute detail of all the circumstances

carried on in conjunction with the French govern
ment to avert, if possible, the crisis which had ar


sen. He also took view Of the various treaties by

serving that no'hing but case which his majesty S
ministers deemed of psramonn, necessity could

pledge as they now required In conclusion Mr..

il not war. (Cheers.j The object of this measure

Friday Evening, Jan. l2. 1897.


The Senate and House Of Representatives con-
vened in the Senate Chamber At O'Clock this even
ing. for the purpose oil choosing a Senator in the
place Of Nicholas Vandyke. Esq. dec, and upon
the first ballot Henry M. Rdgely received l6 votes,
Thomas Cooper 4 votes, Daniel Rodney voics
and Arnold Naudan votes. There were 4 blank
votes.


The two Houses having separa,ed in lew min
utrs again convened fof the purpose o! choosing a
Senator in the place OF Themas Clayton. Esq, and
upon the 6rst bso, Louis nj Iene received 20 votes
Thomas Clayton votes, Arnold Nsudsin vote,
and Samuel II. Black vote. There was also one
blank vote.


From these votes il results that HENRY nj
RIpcELY is chosen Senator TO represent this STATE
in the Senate of the United States until the 4th Of
March, 1S29--and LOUIS MLANE Senator to re
present this State in the Senate oil the United States
Tor years from the Sd Of March next.

Mr.. Mitchell Of S c. opposed, very decidedly
any legislation the subject, and Messrs Bachdn

The question was then taken on ,hc resolution Of

Ressed That the b tor the relief of the sii viving

der be computed and divided among them IN propor-
nn the rank they held, and the time he' we're u SER
wee and also make provision for the eidaus ot such
officer, AMI soldiers, whO we're slain, or otherwise died
while IN sew ce, or mo have since died "


And decided, by yeas and nays, as follows


Yeas, so. Nays, 100.

full articles.headline:
.Npr FORK, jan. T.
VERY LATE AND IMPORTANT.
full articles.article:
L.


The packets have come up this morning rar-
dly aftee each o,hcr, thai have found imno,si
Die 10 keep pace with the important news they have
brought. The latest intelligence is by the packet
Florida, Capt. Tinkham. from Liverpool, which
sailed on the 10th al December, and the packet
Hudson, which sailed from Cowes on the lo'h Nv
these arri. ais the Edi,ors of the Commercial idrsr
tiser have received cop'ous hes oil papers 10 inc
10th OF December inclusive.


These papers contain the highly important intel
lpeuce that in consequence OF the Invasion OF For.
tuyal by Spanish troops, in conuncuon with tne
Portuguese rebels, supplied by Spain, he Princess
Regent had applied to England for assistance lh's
fact was communicated to both houses OF parliament
by royal message. on The lih OF December. On
the 18th an answer to the address va, moved IN the
house OF lords by Earl Bathurst. aud in the house
of commons, by Mr.. Coming. The fprmer IN he
outset of his observations. sdvetted to the negoia-
lion. at Rio Janero, by Sir Cha les Sua' ~ Order
to show that Eng land had not any n.tance acted
upon the principle Of interference with the domestic
concerns of Portugal. Aludinr 10 the atgre,soDs
OF Spain, he described them as Of character which
clearly demonstrated either an extraordinary degree
of unanimity among the people OF that country IL
their hostility towards Portugal or an underiah
co.operation on the part Of the S anish CO. ernmeni
Earl Bathurst concluded his speech by moving
that humble address be presented 10 his AlaIestt
thanking him for his m1st gracious communica'l"n
and expressing the hope which their Lordshps en-
ter,a,nsd that the measures adopted by his Males
,y's Governmen, would awaken he King Of Spain
10 sense Of his danger, and have the effect OF pre-
venting a recourse to arms while Al the same Tune
their Lordships wer. ready TO afford his Males'y
their cordial concurrence ard support, in MAINTAIN
ing the independence OF Portugal, the oldest and
mos, faithful ally oi Great Bi'an' The molten
Va. received with cheers: and Esrl Bathurst was
succeeded by Lord Holland, the Duke OF Weliiog
ion, and the Marquis OF I4ansdown. all oi whom
warmly applsuded the course pursued by the MIN
istcrs Lord Holland and the Duke os Wellington
both believed the prompt despatch OF body OF troops
10 Portugal would be the sures' means OF preventing
a war The motion carried unsnimouSly.


In the House OF Commons on the same day, Mr.
Canning moved the answer To the Kings message
and made very able and interesting speech lie
entered into a minute detail of all the circumstances
connected with the negotiations hch had bee'
carried on in conjunction with the French govern
ment to avert, if possible, the crisis which had ar


sen. He also took view Of the various treaties by
which England was bound TO protect Portugal OBJ
serving that no'hing but case which his majesty S
ministers deemed of psramonn, necessity could
have induced them to apply to paI lament Tor sue .
pledge as they now required In conclusion Mr..
Canning declared ha, "the object OF this measure
il not war. (Cheers.j The object of this measure
is TO take the last chance for peace 1t (sald he }
you do not 60 to the aid Of Portugal. Portugal Will
be iramped upon, and you will be dlsgraced and
then will come war IN the train of degradation.
tIIear, hear) If you wait i'll Spain has The courage

In consequence of the moderation in the weather last
week all the ard bound vessels which had tcen de-
tanned at Newcastle Except the Scatergood and Adi-
son., left that place Saturday mornng. at O'Clock
number of arrivals mostly coasting vessels announ
ced in the Philadelphia papers of Yesterday The passages
have been very long owing detention in the bay by the
ice one 90 days from Salem-ons 80 days from Hartford
another, 90 days from Richmond, &c.

weather and other circumstances having preseocd the

Among the persons present observe the names Of Mr.

the Secretary of State.

full articles.headline: Ertract Of latter from Dorer. dated
full articles.article:
Friday Evening, Jan. l2. 1897.


The Senate and House Of Representatives con-
vened in the Senate Chamber At O'Clock this even
ing. for the purpose oil choosing a Senator in the
place Of Nicholas Vandyke. Esq. dec, and upon
the first ballot Henry M. Rdgely received l6 votes,
Thomas Cooper 4 votes, Daniel Rodney voics
and Arnold Naudan votes. There were 4 blank
votes.


The two Houses having separa,ed in lew min
utrs again convened fof the purpose o! choosing a
Senator in the place OF Themas Clayton. Esq, and
upon the 6rst bso, Louis nj Iene received 20 votes
Thomas Clayton votes, Arnold Nsudsin vote,
and Samuel II. Black vote. There was also one
blank vote.


From these votes il results that HENRY nj
RIpcELY is chosen Senator TO represent this STATE
in the Senate of the United States until the 4th Of
March, 1S29--and LOUIS MLANE Senator to re
present this State in the Senate oil the United States
Tor years from the Sd Of March next.


To Corresbondents.-Want of compes us 10 defer
several communications


reported that Judge WAY has resigned his seat on
the Bench There applicants for The vacan
MILLIaAr Esq mentioned As the democratic party can
expect selection from their ranks on the present oc
casion, believe that the appointment OF Mr. Mllgan
would be satisfactory to them, would be the elevation
the high office Of Judge, Of any other from amongst
their political opponents These are our sentiments, and
we know that many of our friends in them. MIR
Millgans legal requirements qualify him for the station
making the appointment his moral character is unblemish

The GreeksThe people Of New York City actively
engaged in raising supplies Of cleng and provisions ior
the Greeks. They ought do something for that opPres
scd people, by way If repentance for the unpars
leed acts of fraud and injustice committed BY of the
inhabitants Of that city against them.


We glad learn that similar efforts OF benevoencc
are making in other places We would again remind those
in this neEhborhood who wish TO unite in the charitable
work. that their donations may be left at Eoois .M
the Brandywne whence they will be forwarded to pha
dcphia to be shipped.


We observe by an Albany paper that the capital prize OF

drawn at Newcastle the Sd instant, WAS held BY
Merchant of Batavia, N. Y.


We learn from the New York papers Of yester
day that advces had been received fom Havana to
The Cd inst, stating ,hst Com Porter had arrived
off that place with Mexican irigate, TWO brgs and
schooner. and had tent challenge 10 Com La
borde, commander of the Spanish naval forces al
Havana, who Immediately put to sea with large
frigste, a corvette, and brig. The next arrival
from Havana will probably bring an account of an
engagement between the squadrons. Com PcrteT
had recently captured The Spanish brig Hercules
from Csdz for Havana, with very valuable ca 60
OF quicksilver, &c. The U. S. ship Constellation
arrived u Havana, from Pensacola, on the 24th
ult, all well.
